item.title: Testing whether two integers are different
item.description: Here is a super simple statistics question whose answer I didn’t know until just now: How do you test whether one integer is different from another?

item.title: Hash-ordered treaps
item.description: Hash-ordered treaps are a cool kind of binary search tree. They have the neat property that the mapping from ordered sets to hash-ordered treaps is one-to-one and onto. That is, for every ordered set, there’s exactly one valid hash-ordered treap which represents it.

item.title: You should work at Triplebyte
item.description: Triplebyte, the startup where I work, is hiring. We’re looking for engineers, a writer, a UX designer, and some generalist roles.

item.title: Studying for startup interviews with 'Cracking the Coding Interview'
item.description: Cracking the Coding Interview is by far the most popular interview prep book for software engineers. It’s a great book. But it was written for a few years ago, and software engineering interviews seem to have changed in the meantime, at least in the Silicon Valley engineering culture which I’m most involved in.

item.title: A data structure for range kth-smallest queries
item.description: Suppose I want to maintain a set of people where each has an age and a wealth. I want to be able to quickly insert people, delete people, and answer queries of the form “find the $latex k$th richest person whose age is between $latex x$ and $latex y$”.

item.title: Generalized multi-quickselect
item.description: I’ve been thinking a lot recently about how you find the $latex k$th smallest element in the disjoint union of several data structures.

item.title: Quickselect on multiple sorted arrays
item.description: Edit: Thanks heaps to Evgeny Kluev, the author of that original StackOverflow answer, for noticing that I’d made a mistake in the total time complexity calculation.

item.title: Quickselect on an unordered array and an order statistic tree
item.description: I did this work myself, so there are probably mistakes. I think the conclusion is right though.

item.title: Not thinking of things I can't say
item.description: I noticed recently that I usually don’t think of thoughts which I’m not going to be able to say for political correctness reasons. Occasionally when I talk to people who don’t care about offending progressives, they say really insightful things which I would never have thought of on my own, because my brain just blocks those thoughts out before I can think them.

item.title: Optimize dating for non-interference with platonic relationships
item.description: [content warning—I make a lot of claims that certain ways of hitting on people are much better than other ways. If you have a tendency to freak out about whether you’re a terrible person for being sexually attracted to people, maybe don’t read this.]
